author: Edith Bevin
title: Naked aged care photos land worker on sex offenders register
text:
Map: TAS 
A former Tasmanian aged care worker who took photographs of himself with naked residents without their consent has escaped time in jail but will be listed on the sex offenders register. 
Adam Matthew Pettit was working at the One-Care Barossa Park aged care facility in Glenorchy when he took four pictures of female patients in various states of undress in July 2015. 
The court heard the 32-year-old took "lewd photographs" of himself next to the residents, while he was striking various poses. 
He then sent one of the images to a female colleague. 
She did not report it to management until September after she showed it to her mother, who also worked at the facility. 
Pettit said he could not explain why he took the photographs. 
His lawyer told the court Pettit was going through relationship difficulties at the time, was drinking to excess, and had been suffering anxiety. 
The court heard in a pre-sentence assessment that Pettit said it was "a stupid laugh-out loud joke", and there had been no malice or any sexual connotation intended. 
Magistrate Glenn Hay said it displayed a "lack of insight as to the effect on his victims and their families â€¦ and those who may need the care of aged care facilities and aged care workers in the future." 
He said the aged were often infirm and totally reliant on their carers, and that Pettit's actions had caused grave community concern. 
Magistrate Hay sentenced Petit to two months' jail, wholly suspended on the condition he be of good behaviour for three years, and ordered that he perform 100 hours community service. 
Pettit has been added to the sex offenders register for five years.
